content.text: Lesson 1.2: Commas â€” 4 Types of Commas
Commas are the most common type of punctuation on the English Test. In order to successfully handle comma questions, we need to be familiar with the {4 types of commas} that appear on the ACT.
So far, we have already discussed the first two types of commas in Lesson 1.1. The four types are:
Comma + FANBOYS
Use a comma and a {FANBOYS} (for, and, nor, but, or, yet, so) to join two {independent clauses}.
Example: My alarm clock did not go off this morning, so I arrived late at school.
Dependent clause followed by independent clause
If a sentence has a {dependent clause} followed by an {independent clause}, you must link these with a comma.
Example: While electronic music has become very popular, many people still prefer classic rock.
Unnecessary Information
Commas are used to separate {unnecessary information} from the rest of the sentence. Information is {unnecessary} if we can remove it without fundamentally changing the meaning of the sentence.
Example: Mrs. Ellison, who is known for giving pop quizzes, is my least favorite teacher.
Example: The snowboard in the closet, the one with no stickers on it, needs to be waxed.
Listing
Commas are used when {listing} more than two items and with lists of multiple adjectives modifying the same noun.
Example: The group at the picnic table ordered coconut shrimp, hot wings, and onion rings.
Example: The old, limping dog still managed to complete the 3-mile hike.
Deep Dive: Unnecessary Information Commas

The most common type of comma on the ACT separates {unnecessary information} from the rest of the sentence. Information is {unnecessary} if we can remove it without fundamentally changing the meaning. This information can be before a comma, after a comma, or between two commas.
Example: Sitting behind the table, Mark waited to jump out and surprise his mother.
Example: Dale grabbed his favorite surfboard, the blue and green one, and paddled out.
Example: The real winner, however, had yet to be revealed.
The "Crossing-Out" Trick
For {unnecessary information commas}, you must be able to completely remove the information from the sentence. After removing it, what remains must still be a complete sentence.
How to Test: Cross out the information and read the sentence without it.

items: If it works: The information is {unnecessary} and needs to be set apart by a comma or commas.
If it doesn't work: The information is {necessary} and should not have commas.

content.text: Example: The wooden beam, set at an angle, created an optical illusion. Test: "The wooden beam created an optical illusion." (This works! The commas are correct.)
Unnecessary vs. Necessary Information
Sometimes you must determine if information is truly {unnecessary}.
Necessary (No Commas): The dresses that need to be hemmed are hanging in the closet.
Rationale: If we remove the phrase, we don't know which dresses we are talking about.
Unnecessary (With Commas): Judith, who went to fashion school, designs dresses for a living.
Rationale: We already know who designs the dresses (Judith). The information about fashion school is extra, {unnecessary} detail.
The Names Rule
The ACT loves to test how to punctuate names. The rule depends on {specificity}.
No Commas (Name is Necessary): Use no commas if the identifier before the name is not specific (e.g., friend, teacher, Olympic gold medalist).
Example: My friend Kelly recently moved to London. (Without "Kelly," we don't know which friend).
With Commas (Name is Unnecessary): Use commas if the identifier is specific (e.g., best friend, youngest sister, Amazon CEO).
Example: My best friend, Andrew, is a certified scuba diver. (A person can only have one best friend, so the name "Andrew" is {unnecessary} info).
"That" vs. "Which" Phrases
"That" phrases never get commas. They are always {necessary} information.
Example: The dogs that live down the street are always barking.
"Which" phrases always get commas. They are always {unnecessary} information.
Example: My neighbor's dogs, which are always barking, love to play fetch.
"ing" and "ed" Phrases
These phrases (called {participle phrases}) may or may not get commas, depending on if they are {necessary}.
Unnecessary (With Commas): This is the most common use on the ACT.
Example: Excited for the car ride, Jane's bulldog started to jump up and down.
Example: Marcus applied for the internship, hoping that he would get the position.
Necessary (No Commas): This happens when the phrase specifies which noun you're talking about.
Example: The politician waving to the crowd is predicted to win the election. (Specifies which politician).
Prepositional Phrases
These are phrases starting with prepositions like in, of, to, for, with, on, at, from, etc.
At the start of a sentence: Always followed by a comma.
Example: On my way to work, I listened to my new favorite podcast.
In the middle or end of a sentence: Almost never have commas. They usually contain {essential information}.
Example: The clothing on the bed is for vacation.
Punctuation for Transitional Words (e.g., "However")
Words like {however}, {therefore}, {moreover}, {consequently}, and {for example} have 3 specific punctuation rules:
At the start of a sentence: Followed by a comma.
Example: However, the truth would not be revealed until next week.
In the middle of one sentence: Separated by two commas (as {unnecessary information}).
Example: The truth, however, would not be revealed until next week.
Between two independent clauses: Separated by a {semicolon (;) and a comma (,)}.
Example: I expected to pay over $100; however, I found a sale.
Deep Dive: Listing Commas
Listing commas are the easiest type and appear in two ways.
Commas and Lists (3 or more items)
Use commas to separate items in a list of {3 or more}.
Example: I went to the grocery store to pick up chicken, cheese, and bread.

The Oxford Comma: The final comma (before the "and") is the {Oxford comma}. The ACT is stylistic about this; its presence or absence alone will never be the only difference between a right and wrong answer.
Lists of 2 Items: Be sure not to use commas in a list of just two items.
Incorrect: Mike cashed out his winnings, and then headed back to his hotel room.
Correct: Mike cashed out his winnings and then headed back to his hotel room.
FANBOYS vs. Lists
Be careful not to confuse a {two-item list} (no comma) with a {Comma + FANBOYS} rule (which needs a comma).
Two-item list (no comma): The debate team took first place in California and then won the grand prize... (The second half is not an independent clause).
Comma + FANBOYS (needs comma): Andrew left to get his suit, but he forgot and just grabbed a cheeseburger... (The second half is an independent clause).
Adjective Lists with and without Commas
Listing commas are also used to separate multiple adjectives modifying the same noun.
Example: The wet, smelly dog was excited for the car ride home.
The Rule: You must know when to use commas and when not to.

items: Use a comma if you can switch the order of the adjectives and the sentence still makes sense.
No comma if switching the order changes the meaning or makes no sense.

content.text: The "Switching Trick"
When you see multiple adjectives, switch their order to test for a comma.
Example: The sweet cold ice cream...
Test: "The cold sweet ice cream..." (This makes sense, so you need a comma).
Correct: The sweet, cold ice cream...
Example: Elliot had to take off his stainless steel necklace...
Test: "Elliot had to take off his steel stainless necklace..." (This makes no sense, so you do not use a comma).
Correct: ...his stainless steel necklace.
Summary: Commas and Sentence Structure
Here are the most common ways sentence structure and comma rules appear on the ACT.
Comma + FANBOYS (IC, and IC)
Example: The researchers changed their approach, and they created a new medical procedure.
Independent Clause + Unnecessary Phrase (IC, phrase.)
Example: The researchers changed their approach, creating a new medical procedure.
Unnecessary Phrase + Independent Clause (Phrase, IC.)
Example: Determined to find a cure, the researchers changed their approach.
Dependent Clause + Independent Clause (DC, IC.)
Example: Since they were determined to find a cure, the researchers changed their approach.
Phrase, IC, Phrase
Example: Determined to find a cure, the researchers changed their approach, creating a new medical procedure.
Independent Clause + Necessary Phrase (No comma)
Example: The researchers changed their approach by creating a new medical procedure.
List with 2 items (No comma)
Example: The researchers changed their approach and created a new medical procedure.
Phrase, Phrase, IC
Example: Despite the company's efforts, which included offering a 75% refund, Claire was still disappointed.
DC, IC, Phrase
Example: As the curtains closed, the crowd stood and applauded, many with tears in their eyes.
The "1-Comma" Rule
This is a powerful final rule: When a sentence has {only one comma} in the middle, there must be an {independent clause} on one side of the comma, but not both and not neither.

items: If both sides are independent = Comma Splice (Incorrect).
If neither side is independent = Sentence Fragment (Incorrect).
Correct Use: Unnecessary information, independent clause.
Correct Use: Dependent clause, independent clause.
Correct Use: Independent clause, unnecessary information.

content.text: KEY TAKEAWAYS
